text.content: DEAR HENLEY, - We are all to pieces in health, and heavily handicapped with Arabs.
I have a dreadful cough, whose attacks leave me AETAT. 90.
I never let up on the Arabs, all the same, and rarely get less than eight pages out of hand, though hardly able to come downstairs for twittering knees.
He says so little of his circumstances that I am in an impossibility to give him advice more specific than a copybook.
Give him my love, however, and tell him it is the mark of the parochial gentleman who has never travelled to find all wrong in a foreign land.
Let him hold on, and he will find one country as good as another; and in the meanwhile let him resist the fatal British tendency to communicate his dissatisfaction with a country to its inhabitants.
'Tis a good idea, but it somehow fails to please.
In a fortnight, if I can keep my spirit in the box at all, I should be nearly through this Arabian desert; so can tackle something fresh.
